text:
Tall can.
Black pour that shows some ruby at the edges. Small tan head.
Complex aroma, lightly burnt dark roast coffee, chocolate and vanilla.
The flavor has both sweet and bitter with all of the flavors suggested in th aroma coming in. Smooth, full bodied.
Opaque black with a medium sized tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Roasted malts, lighter cocoa, lactose, coffee, sweeter finish.

Pint at the brewery. Black beer with a tan head. The coffee character exceeds my expectation, immediately jumping out in the aroma. Its ashy, fruity like berries, and gives reasonable roast. The mouthfeel is full, supporting the massive latte flavors. Milky sweetness balances things out in the flavor with hints at chocolate with a far-off ashtray finish. I like the bold use of coffee, great example of the style.
Everything is awesome about this beer. Great balance. Great flavor. The body is very heavy. If it was a bit lighter on the palate... you got a perfect beer. That coffee... so good.
Dark brown color, opaque, brown head. Aroma of lightly burnt espresso. Taste has earthy coffee, bitter cocoa. Very tasty.

Sample at the taproom (as "Tin Cup Camp Stout"). Brown-black color with a medium foamy tan head that diminishes steadily to an outer ring. Partial rings of lacing. Roast malt, coffee and chocolate aroma. Light to medium body with a roasty coffee and malt character, with some milk chocolate in the background. The The finish is roasty coffee and chocolate. Pretty good overall.

On the menu at The Porter as "Tin Cup Camp Stout". Pours a deep brownish black on tap with fluffy tan brown head that leaves moderate lace. Aroma of a hint of smoke under big dark roast coffee notes and a touch of earth. Taste follows, but add a bit of sweet milk chocolate. Really nicely balanced stout, tasty.
16 oz can from Ale Yeah. bittersweet coffee and cocoa. some chocolate on the finish. complex and deep for a 5.6er. light and somewhat sweet aroma.

On tap at the brewery listed as "Tin Cup Coffee Stout" same 5.6%. Black with a tan head. Aroma is cold coffee. Taste is lots of very bitter coffee, almost like drinking a very powerful cold roast. Touch of chocolate and roast. Definitely more coffee than beer. Body is coffee thin, low carbonation.
Nice stout. A little on the thin side for a stout, but nice roastiness and coffee.

Dark brown/black pour with thick tan head and lace. Large coffee aroma with some roasted malts. Flavor is sweet coffee, light chocolate, and roasted malt. A good malt bitter finish as well. Medium bodied with smooth carbonation. a solid beer that I like
Strong coffee aromas, dark chocolate, caramel, vanilla. Black with a mostly lasting beige head. Dry, roasty, nutty. Full bodied.
Aromas of maple and light coffee. Bone head and black body. Spicey cocoa and coffee flavors with some minor maple sweetness. Smooth but a little heat on the palate.

On tap at the brewery taproom. Listed as 7% ABV and 44 IBU.

Pours essentially black with a good head and very good lacing.

Aroma: exceptionally fine coffee with a trace of black bread. 

Flavor: supreme coffee flavor. Just the right amount of mild bitterness.  his is the best tasting coffee beer Ive ever had! The coffee flavor is fairly strong and dominant but not too strong: theres some nice dark bread elements too. 

Very smooth, near full body with low but near perfect carbonation. 

Overall: superb coffee stout!

Draft at taproom. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Big bitter coffee notes on the nose. I can't say I'm getting much of the lactose but I love the bitterness of the coffee. I find that bitterness refreshing compared to most of the style. Nice. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught at brewery. Really big coffee nose and taste. Some burnt chocolate. Roast. Richer than the abv. Very good.

Growler from the brewery. Pours jet black into the glass with a nice tan head that leaves trace lacing. The nose is of nice morning coffee... just beautiful! Flavors of roasted coffee, bitter chocolates, dark berries and lactose sugars finish with a hint of ginger and licorice. The mouthfeel is beautifully crafted; smooth and coffee-esque, deeply complex and substantial. Just a gorgeous cross between a rich coffee stout and smooth, easy-drinking milk stout. Have your coffee and cream in this awesome offering! Keep it up, Burial. The best beer in Asheville, Ill say it again. Nothing but quality from this superb brewery.
